entries: You know the {@spell poison spray} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell fog cloud} spell once, and it recharges after a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell misty step} spell once, and it recharges after a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Hidden Step
entries: As a bonus action, you can magically turn {@condition invisible} until the start of your next turn or until you attack, make a damage roll, or force someone to make a saving throw. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Mask of the Wild
entries: You can attempt to {@action hide} even when you are only lightly obscured by foliage, heavy rain, falling snow, mist, and other natural phenomena.

Chameleos dragonborn scales are purple, though their limbs and stomach are bare, showing off-white skin. They have long, elastic tongues, but unlike the Chameleos, the dragonborn's eyes do not resemble a chameleon's in shape. Instead, their iris and pupil simulate the look.

entries.name: Dalamadur Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed, and magic can't put you to sleep.

entries.name: Elder Dragon Magic
entries: You know the {@spell fire bolt} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell charm person} spell once, and it recharges after a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell melf's minute meteors|XGE} spell once, and it recharges after a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

Dalamadur dragonborn have a snake-like face, with bright red eyes, numerous fangs. Their body is covered in thick black and gray scales with many hook-like spikes along their body which start out clustered around their head and neck. When angered, their face and chest will glow red.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Elder Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed, and frightened.

entries.name: Shifting Scales
entries: Your scales change color daily. This determines your draconic resistance and breath weapon for the day. Each day at dawn, roll a d3 and refer to the table below to determine your scale's color.

entries.name: Black Fire
entries: When you use your breath weapon, you exhale black flames in a 15-foot cone. The damage dealt by this breath weapon is half necrotic and half fire. If the damage die is odd, the last die is dealt as necrotic damage.

entries.name: Crimson Demon's Breath
entries: When you use your breath weapon, you exhale black flames in a 5 by 30-foot line. The damage dealt by this breath weapon is half necrotic and half fire. If the damage die is odd, the last die is dealt as fire damage.

entries.name: Emperor's Roar
entries: When you use your breath weapon, you let out a cacophonous roar, calling down red lightning that strikes down in a 5-foot radius around you. The damage dealt by this breath weapon is lightning damage.

Fatalis dragonborn look similar to a regular dragonborn, except each day their scales change color. Fatalis dragonborn that live within society tend to only show themselves when they are one color, or cover themselves almost entirely. Outcasts or those who lean more towards evil, proudly show their heritage at all times.

entries.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to lightning damage.

entries.name: Elder Dragon Magic
entries: You know the {@spell thaumaturgy} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell thunderwave} spell once, and it recharges after a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell shatter} spell once, and it recharges after a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Control Lightning
entries: Whenever you cast {@filter a spell that deals lightning or thunder damage|spells|damage type=lightning;thunder}, you can cast it as if you were in a space within 15 feet of your actual location.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

Amatsumagatsuchi dragonborn's head is adorned with large golden horns. Their scales are largely pale white and fins that stretch across all four limbs and back. Many of them are known to wear long flowing clothing, as a representation of amatsumagatsuchi's webbing, while others use it as a means to hide the fact that their feet never touch the ground.

entries.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Glorious Dragonborn
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Persuasion} skill.

entries.name: Metallic Coat
entries: As part of a long rest, you can produce apowerful magnetic force that attracts metals and minerals from the ground to your body and melt them with your high body temperature before letting it cool on your body, forming a metal coat. While wearing this metallic coat, your AC is 17, but your movement speed is reduced by 5 feet.

As an action you can shed the coat by entering a super heated state. Your super heated state lasts for 1 minute or until you end it as a bonus action. During it, once on each of your turns, you can deal extra fire damage to one target when you deal damage to it with an attack or a spell. The extra fire damage equals your level.

Kulve taroth dragonborn are slim and muscular with dark blue and golden scales covered by a metallic mantle (typically gold). They have large spiraling horns that resemble lapis lazuli, when they aren't covered in gold plating.

entries.name: Acclimated
entries: You're acclimated to high altitude, including elevations above 20,000 feet. You're also naturally adapted to cold climates.

entries.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to thunder damage.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: Due to the constant oxidation of your metal scales, any armor you wear rusts rapidly. Your scales provide ample protection, however; it gives you a base AC of 17 (your Dexterity modifier doesn't affect this number). You gain no benefit from wearing armor, but if you are using a shield, you can apply the shield's bonus as normal.

entries.name: Wind Barrier
entries: You can use an action to summon a barrier of wind around you for 1 minute. While the barrier is active, you have half cover against range attacks, resistance to nonmagical ammunition, and disperse any fog like effect in a 5-foot radius around you. Once used, you can't use this trait again until you finish a long rest.

Recognized by their two backward curving horns that blend in with the spikes lining their back and their organic metallic scales, the kushala dragonborn are steel willed defenders. Their mantra is "a cracked scale will lead to a dragon's downfall". So they train themselves and others to the best of their ability, to protect their beliefs.

The Kushala dragonborn scales are almost a pristine silver when they are born and begin to oxidize, darkening and rusting, as they age. To counteract the rust, the dragonborn molts as it grows, like a snake, shedding its old scales and beginning the process anew. Until their elder years when their molting ceases and they slowly turn the orange-red brown color of rust over the entirety of their body.

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe air and water.

entries.name: Bone Armor
entries: As part of a short rest or long rest, you can harvest the bones from a slain creature of size Small or larger and adhere them to your body, gaining a number of temporary hit points equal to 1/2 the creature's CR. To use this trait, you need a blade, such as a {@item dagger|PHB}, or appropriate artisan's tools, such as {@item woodcarver's tools|PHB}.

entries.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Nakarkos Beams
entries: From your hands you fire two 5 by 15 foot lines of draconic energy that deal necrotic damage (Con. save). A creature in the line of more than one beam is affected only once. The damage and save DCs are the same as a dragonborn's breath weapon. After using your nakarkos beams, you cannot use them again until you complete a short or long rest.

entries.name: Sticky Mucus
entries: You secrete a sticky liquor through your skin. You have advantage on Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks to climb, grapple, or prevent yourself from being disarmed; but you also have disadvantage when attempting to escape a grapple.

Dragonborn only by name and silhouette, the nakarkos dragonborn are actually cephalopod-like humanoids. They have glowing yellow eyes and blue skin with spots of turquoise bioluminescence. The nakarkos dragonborn are able to secrete a sticky mucus from their pores, using it to adhere the bones of slain creatures to their body.

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe air and water.

entries.name: Breath Weapon
entries: Your breath weapon is a 5 by 30 foot line (Con. save) that deals cold damage.

entries.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to your choice of one of the following damage types: cold damage or lightning damage.

entries.name: Waterbending
entries: You know the {@spell shape water|XGE} cantrip.

Namielle dragonborn have large needle-shaped teeth, like a deep-sea fish, and may have multiple long whiskers that resemble jellyfish-like tendrils. Normally their body is colored black and a deep sea blue, accented by a vibrant red while parts of their face and limbs glow with a bioluminescent light that pulses with the colors of the rainbow. When they haven't spent time in the rain or in water, their scales dry out changing to a milky tan coloring.

entries.name: Horns
entries: Your horns are natural weapons, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with them, you deal bludgeoning damage equal to 1d6 + your Strength modifier.

entries.name: Indurate Spikes
entries: You can cast {@spell shield of faith} with this trait, but only target yourself. When you use this version of shield of faith, you have advantage on Constitution saving throws to maintain concentration on this spell. Once you cast this spell, you can't cast it again with this trait until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Menacing
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Intimidation} skills.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: You have tough, scaly skin. When you aren't wearing armor, your AC is 13 + your Dexterity modifier. You can use your natural armor to determine your AC if the armor you wear would leave you with a lower AC. A shield's benefits apply as normal while you use your natural armor.

entries.name: Spiked Regrowth
entries: As an action, you can regain a number of hit points equal to your level + your Constitution modifier. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

Nergigante dragonborn have a bristly appearance. Much like their elder dragon brethren, their scales are black with purple and orange accents and sport two bulbous horns atop their head. The regenerative properties of the nergigante still flow in the blood of this elder dragonborn, though at a much slower rate. Taking hours to regrow their spikes instead of seconds.

entries.name: Breath Weapon
entries: Your breath weapon deals thunder damage in a 5-foot wide by 30-foot long line (CON save).

entries.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to thunder damage.

entries.name: Perceptive
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Perception} skill.

entries.name: Stone Shell
entries: As an action, you gain 1d4 + 4 temporary hit points for 1 hour. At 3rd level you gain an additional 5 temporary hit points. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

The shara ishvalda dragonborn are as mysterious as the elder dragon they share their lineage with. The dragonborn from this ancestry share a strange trait in which they always seem to be endlessly gazing at something that's just right past you. Although this gaze never meets your eyes, one can't help but feel they're looking at the real you. Their bodies are lithe and athletic, boasting a variety of bright colors, mainly yellows, purples, and white. They are known to manipulate the earth to surround their body, using their innate ability to control vibration, though they are not as skilled as their elder dragon ancestors.

entries.name: Draconic Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against disease, and you have resistance against acid damage.

entries.name: Effluvium Aura
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use your action to unleash effluvium stored within yourself, causing miasma to emanate in a 5-foot radius around you for 1 minute, or until you end it as a bonus action. When a creature starts its turn in the effluvium or enters it for the first time on a turn, that creature takes 2 (1d4) acid damage.
The damage increases to 1d6 at 7th level, 1d8 at 11th, and 1d10 at 16th level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Effluvium Magic
entries: When you reach 5th level, you can cast the {@spell bestow curse} spell once, and it recharges after a long rest. wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells. If the nature of the curse targets one of the creature's Ability Score, you have advantage on Constitution saving throws to maintain concentration on the spell and the spell acts as if it was casted as a 4th-level spell.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

Vaal hazak dragonborn's are typically slender and covered in silver scales, which are obscured by the fleshy red veil that covers most of their body. Similar to its elder dragon relative, the elder dragonborn vaal hazak, has the ability to transform the effluvium created by the bacteria on its body, into magic.

entries.name: Draconic Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against disease, and you have resistance against acid damage.

entries.name: Effluvium Explosion
entries: As an action you create an explosion of spores that fill a 30-foot sphere centered on you for 1 minute, until a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it, or you use the effluvium spore trait. The sphere spreads around corners, and its area is lightly obscured.

While you remain in the spores, you know the location of all creatures and objects in the area, creatures or objects in the area can't benefit from being invisible, and you can use an action to cover one creature or object in spores.

The spores remain on the creature for the next 24 hours, or until they completely submerge their body and anything they were wearing or carrying (when the spores attached to it) in water for 5 minutes. For the duration, you know the location of the creature or object if you are within 30 feet of it.

entries.name: Effluvium Spores
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use your action to cause the effluvium spores on your body to float in a 5-foot radius around you for 1 minute, or until you end it as a bonus action. Additionally, as a bonus action you can send your spores to a location of your choosing within 30 feet of you. The spores fill a 10-foot-squared area that is 5 feet tall and remain in that location until they deal damage to a creature, or your effluvium spore duration ends. At the start of your next turn, a new set of spores floats around you once again.

When a creature starts its turn in the spore's area or enters it for the first time on a turn, that creature takes 2 (1d4) acid damage. The damage increases to 1d6 at 7th level, 1d8 at 11th, and 1d10 at 16th level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

Vaal hazak dragonborn's are typically slender and covered in silver scales, which are obscured by the fleshy red veil that covers most of their body. Similar to its elder dragon relative, the elder dragonborn vaal hazak, has the ability to transform the effluvium created by the bacteria on its body, into magic.

entries.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to necrotic damage.

entries.name: The Red Comet
entries: Your ability to discharge draconic energy from your hands or wings allows you to move with a burst of speed that resembles a red comet traveling through space. When you move on your turn in combat, you can double your speed until the end of the turn. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you move 0 feet on one of your turns.

entries.name: Valstrax Lineage
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use your action to unleash the draconic energy within yourself, causing your eyes to glow red and two trident-like, wings to sprout from your back.

Your transformation lasts for 1 minute or until you end it as a bonus action. During it, you have a flying speed of 30 feet, and once on each of your turns, you can deal extra fire damage to one target when you deal damage to it with an attack or a spell. The extra fire damage equals your level.
Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.
Valstrax dragonborn are typically slender and covered in gleaming silver scales with blue eyes. Their backs are lined with fin-like projections.

entries.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to necrotic damage.

entries.name: Ignition
entries: You can use your action to discharge dragon element energy from your hands in one of the following ways: as a 5 by 30 ft. line, a 15 ft. cone, or in a 5-foot radius around you. When you use your ignition, each creature in the area of the discharge must make a Dexterity saving throw. The DC for this saving throw equals 8 + your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus. A creature takes 2d6 necrotic damage on a failed save, and half as much damage on a successful one. The damage increases to 3d6 at 6th level, 4d6 at 11th level, and 5d6 at 16th level. After you use your ignition, you can't use it again until you complete a short or long rest.

entries.name: Valstrax Lineage
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use your action to unleash the draconic energy within yourself, causing your eyes to glow red and two trident-like, wings to sprout from your back.

Your transformation lasts for 1 minute or until you end it as a bonus action. During it, you have a flying speed of 30 feet, and once on each of your turns, you can deal extra fire damage to one target when you deal damage to it with an attack or a spell. The extra fire damage equals your level.
Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.
Valstrax dragonborn are typically slender and covered in gleaming silver scales with blue eyes. Their backs are lined with fin-like projections.

entries.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to cold damage.

entries.name: Frost Breath
entries: You know the {@spell ray of frost} cantrip. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for it.

entries.name: Glacial Grace
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Acrobatics} and {@skill Persuasion} skills.

entries.name: Ice Armor
entries: You know the {@spell armor of agathys} spell. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast it as a 2nd-level spell. When you reach 5th level you can cast it as a 3rd-level spell. Once you use this trait, you cannot use it again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Ice Walk
entries: You can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost you extra moment.

Velkhana dragonborn are elegant and slim. Their scales are a unique crystalline blue, and their head has a tiara-like crown of small horns. The velkhana dragonborn have the unique ability to summon ice to cover their bodies, providing additional protection. They also can use this ice offensively against those who attack them.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Felynes are most often good. Those who tend toward law are found in villages working as adventurers, chefs, farmers, or traders. Those who tend toward chaos are from the wilderness and live off the land as scavengers and hunters. Felyne are good-hearted and even the tricksters among them are more playful than vicious.

entries.name: Adaptive Fighter
entries: You are proficient with improvised weapons.

entries.name: Felyne Magic
entries: You know the {@spell friends} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell calm emotions} spell once per day. When you reach 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell suggestion} spell once per day. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Meowster Chef
entries: You have proficiency with {@item cook's utensils|PHB}.

entries.name: Cultured
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Persuasion} skill.
Felynes are recognized by their white fur and have the ability to talk in human language, and can be found both in human villages and in the wild.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Melynx tend toward chaotic alignments as they let impulse, curiosity, and mischievousness guide their decisions. Melynx that grow up in villages tend towards good, but those mistreated or those who grew up in the wilderness lean towards neutral or evil.

entries.name: Cat's Claws
entries: Because of your claws, you have a climbing speed of 20 feet. In addition, your claws are natural weapons, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with them, you deal slashing damage equal to 1d4 + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

entries.name: Kleptomaniac
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Sleight of Hand} skill. Additionally, you are able to determine the value of an object you have stolen,if you spend at least 1 hour inspecting or studying it without interruption. If the item is magical, you know its rarity, but not what its magical properties are.

entries.name: Meowster Chef
entries: You have proficiency with {@item cook's utensils|PHB}.
Melynx are noted for their black fur and the ability to talk in human language, as well as do human activities like their fellow Lynian subspecies called the Felynes.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Shakalaka are typically neutral evil, as they care only for their own needs. A few shakalaka might tend toward good or neutrality, but only rarely.

entries.name: Aggressive
entries: You pursue foes relentlessly, even at great risk to yourself. As a bonus action, you may move up to your speed towards a hostile creature you can see.

entries.name: Mask of the Wild
entries: You can attempt to {@action hide} even when you are only lightly obscured by foliage, heavy rain, falling snow, mist, and other natural phenomena.

entries.name: Natural Athlete
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Athletics} skill.

entries.name: Shakalaka Weapon Training
entries: You have proficiency with the {@item club|PHB}, {@item greatclub|PHB}, {@item morningstar|PHB}, and {@item warhammer|PHB}.
Shakalaka are small, humanoid creatures with green skin. They wear a mask over their heads at all times, so their true faces are unknown.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most grimalkynes are good and rarely choose sides when it comes to law and chaos. Tribal leaders and warriors might be lawful, while explorers and adventurers might tend toward chaotic.

entries.name: Keen Hearing
entries: You have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing.

entries.name: Tracker
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Nature} and {@skill Survival} skills.

entries.name: Grimalkyne Weapon Training
entries: You have proficiency with the {@item glaive|PHB}, {@item javelin|PHB}, {@item net|PHB}, and {@item trident|PHB}.
Grimalkyne resemble bipedal lynxes. They have tufted ears, and come in a variety of colors depending on the tribe.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Gajalaka are proud and barbaric, and are not strongly inclined toward good. They are slow to trust, but once someone gains the trust of a gajalaka, they are considered an ally for life, or until proven otherwise.

entries.name: Herbalist
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Nature} skill.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You have proficiency with {@item poisoner's kit|PHB}.

entries.name: Tribal Mask
entries: You have a red tribal mask that is accented by a color. Choose one color from the Tribal Mask table. Your gaja knife and your gajalaka tolerance is determined by the color of the mask's accents, as shown in the table.
Should this mask be destroyed, you can recreate a new one during a long or short rest, but the accent color cannot change.

entries.caption: Tribal Mask Table
rows: Until the end of your next turn.

entries: {@i *A creature may repeat its saving throw for this condition at the end of each of its turns}

entries.name: Gaja Knife
entries: Your knife is coated with viscous liquid that is an opaque color, similar to the color of your mask's accents. You're proficient with this knife, and it has the finesse and thrown property, with a normal range of 20 and a long range of 40. When you hit with a weapon attack using it, the target takes 1d4 + your Dexterity modifier as piercing damage and they must make a Constitution saving throw.

The DC for this saving throw equals 8 + your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus. On a failed save, the creature is afflicted with the condition based on your mask's accent color and lasts for the duration listed in the Tribal Mask table.
After you hit a creature with this knife, it shatters. During a short or long rest, you can create a new gaja knife, but you can never carry more than one at a time.

entries.name: Gajalaka Tolerance
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against the condition associated with your tribal mask.

Gajalaka are short humanoids. They resemble Shakalaka more than Felynes or Grimalkynes, lacking any fur and wearing large tribal masks which leave only their bright yellow eyes visible. These red masks have different color accents, ranging from blue to yellow to purple, to represent what status ailment their weapons afflict. The Gajalaka in the Caverns of El Dorado have golden masks.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Boaboa tends toward neutrality, being more focused on survival than concepts of good and evil. A sense of community can drive boaboas toward lawful alignments.

entries.name: Frost Resistance
entries: You have resistance to cold damage.

entries.name: Ice Walk
entries: You can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra moment.

entries.name: Tribal Mask
entries: You have a mask that is a crude imitation of a popo's head that has its tusks painted a color. Choose one color from the Popo Mask table. Your boa javelin and your gajalaka tolerance is determined by the color of the mask's accents, as shown in the table.
Should this mask be destroyed, you can recreate a new one during a long or short rest, but the accent color cannot change.

entries.caption: Popo Mask Table
rows: Until the end of your next turn.

entries: {@i *A creature may repeat its saving throw for this condition at the end of each of its turns}

entries.name: Boa Javelin
entries: Your javelin's blade is coated with a viscous liquid that is an opaque color, similar to the color of your mask's tusks. When you hit a creature with it, they take damage as normal, but they must also make a Constitution saving throw.

The DC for this saving throw equals 8 + your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus. On a failed save, the creature is afflicted with the condition based on your mask's tusk color and lasts for the duration listed in the Popo Mask table.
After you hit a creature with this javelin, the javelin breaks. During a short or long rest, you can create a new javelin, but you can never carry more than one boa javelin at a time.

entries.name: Boaboa Tolerance
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against the condition associated with your tribal mask.

The Boaboa have the basic shape of a Grimalkyne, but exhibit much thicker, white fur and a bulkier frame. They wear crude imitations of Popo heads as masks, with the tusk's tips painted in colours that correspond to the status ailment each individual Boaboa uses in combat.

entries.name: Modern Magic
entries: You know the {@spell create bonfire|XGE} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell enlarge/reduce} spell once per day. When you reach 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell blindness/deafness} spell once per day. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You have proficiency in two {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

entries.name: Wyverian Weapon Training
entries: You have proficiency with two {@filter martial weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon} of your choice.

Modern wyverians peacefully coexist with humans and often live among them, especially older modern wyverians, past their prime. Younger Wyverians are known to travel far and wide, often accompanying humans. Modern wyverians are usually between 20 and 200 years old.

entries.name: Ancient Magic
entries: You know the {@spell druidcraft} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell barkskin} spell once per day. When you reach 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell earthbind|XGE} spell once per day. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Kit Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with the kit of your choice: {@item herbalism kit|PHB} or {@item poisoner's kit|PHB}.

entries.name: Mask of the Wild
entries: You can attempt to {@action hide} even when you are only lightly obscured by foliage, heavy rain, falling snow, mist, and other natural phenomena.

entries.name: Survivor
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Survival} skill.

Ancient wyverian are the wyverian who survived the Great Dragon War and may even remember the time of the ancient civilization. They are small in stature, sometimes a bit stubborn, but always seek to help those lost in the world. Ancient wyverians are usually between 600 and 1000 years old.

table.name: Bonepiles
rows: Just a bone. So worn and weathered, it's unidentifiable.
Bone ammunition casing. Stronger than a Huskberry.
Bone ammunition casing that can withstand powerful explosions.
Resource used to upgrade weapons to Uncommon.
Resource used to upgrade armor to Uncommon.
Resource used to upgrade armor to Uncommon.
Resource used to upgrade armor to Rare.
Resource used to upgrade armor to Rare.
Resource used to upgrade weapon to Rare.
Resource used to upgrade armor to Very Rare.
Resource used to upgrade weapons to Very Rare.
Resource used to upgrade armor to any rarity.
footnotes: When you go searching for bones, you will typically find them only in lairs. You may also find them, rarely, out in the open depending on the environment you are in.

When you succeed on an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to locate a bonepile in an area, You must then make a Wisdom ({@skill Nature}) or Intelligence ({@skill History}) check against the locations Bonepile resource DC. On a success, you roll on the locations bonepile resources table.

table.name: Fish
rows: A fish that explodes when killed.
A fish that ruptures open when killed.
A fish with a jaw covered in tiny needle-like spikes
A delicious fish that restores 1d4 hit points when consumed.
A fish with a dorsal fin hard enough to be used to sharpen weapons.
A fish that literally pops when it dies.
When a creature ingests this fish, they must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or gain one level of {@condition exhaustion}.
A fish that emits blue light. Its sharp body will cut you to pieces if you're not careful. Deals 1 piercing damage when picked up.
Will devour anything in its path, and sometimes these remain inside. Contains one random material or additional resource.
A curiously small, rare, gold fish. Commands a high price.
A fish which can be used as an upgrade material for any armor or weapon rarity.
A rare and valuable giant-sized fish.

Can be cooked by making a DC 20 {@item cook's utensils|PHB|Cooking Utensil} check. On a successful check, the gastronome tuna acts as the {@spell Heroes' Feast} spell. On a failed save, the tuna is burnt and inedible.
footnotes: When you succeed on an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to locate a fishing spot,you must then make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check against the location's Fish resource DC. On a success, you roll on the location's fish resources table.
*All Fish can be eaten raw as a day's ration.

table.name: Insects
rows: Can increase soil fertility. You have a +1 bonus to fishing skill checks when used as bait.
Contains a bitter essence. Has a 50% chance of curing poison if consumed.
An insect that exudes a scent that drives fish wild. You have a +1 bonus to fishing skill checks when used as bait.
Viscous body fluids and sharp jaws make this insect an artisan.
Energetic insect that works well as fishing bait. You have a +2 bonus to fishing skill checks when used as bait.
A firefly that's always glowing. You have a +1 bonus to fishing skill checks when used as bait.
You can add this to a potion, increasing the amount it heals you by 1d4. ({@item alchemist's supplies|PHB|Alchemy} DC 10) You cannot add more than one to a potion.
The remains of a dead insect.
A snake-like larva with a scent that fish just love. You have a +3 bonus to fishing skill checks when used as bait.
An insect that emits a powerful flash when it dies.
An insect said to live for a thousand years.
An insect that emits electricity when struck. Has many applications.
A beautiful bell cricket resembling a flower. Its sound opens even the hardest of hearts.
You can make a DC 10 {@item Poisoner's Kit|PHB} check, to crush the bug and extract its poison into a single vial. This poison acts as the {@item Serpent Venom|DMG} poison (DMG p.258).
A grasshopper with an exceptionally strong shell.
You can make a DC 15 {@item Poisoner's Kit|PHB} check, to crush the bug and extract its poison into a single vial. This poison acts as {@item Wyvern Poison|DMG} (DMG p.258).
Its giant horn and massive shell give it a rare, butterfly-like beauty.
The Royal Class of the scarabs, with a hard shell and lustrous wings.
Rarely seen by humans, its wings shimmer like precious gems.
footnotes: When you succeed on an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to locate insects of interest in an area, you must then make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) or Wisdom ({@skill Nature}) check against the locations Insect resource DC. On a success, you roll on the locations insect resources table.

table.name: Minerals
rows: Resource used to upgrade armor to Uncommon.
Resource used to upgrade a weapon to Uncommon.
Ice that will not melt at room temperature.
Resource used to upgrade armor to Rare. Can be traded to the smithy for two Armor Spheres.
Resource used to upgrade a weapon to Rare. Can be traded to the smithy for two Earth Crystals.
Resource used to upgrade a weapon to Very Rare. Can be traded to the smithy for two Machalite Ore.
Resource used to upgrade armor to Very Rare. Can be traded to the smithy for two Hard Armor Spheres.
Long worshipped as a source of life. You can use an action to cast the {@spell light} cantrip from the crystals for 1 hour. They shatter when the light fades.
Same effect as a gypceros lightcrystal.
Resource used to upgrade a weapon to Legendary. Can be traded to the smithy for two Dragonite Ore.
Resource used to upgrade armor to Legendary. Can be traded to the smithy for two Heavy Armor Spheres.
footnotes: When you go searching for minerals, you will typically find them only in caves. You may also find them, very rarely, on rocky outcroppings in the wilds depending on the environment you are in.

When you succeed on an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to locate a mining node in an area, You must then make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check against the locations Mineral resource DC. On a success, you roll on the locations mineral resources table.

table.name: Mushrooms
rows: Common mushroom with a power-enhancing effect.
A poisonous fungus. Counts as 1 days ration when eaten, but the creature must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw, or be {@condition poisoned} for 24 hours.
A common mushroom with the power to generate heat. Acts as a campfire for 8 hours if crushed on the ground, but generates no light or smoke.
Mushroom that induces a paralysis effect when cooked with meat.
A giant paralyzing mushroom. When a creature plucks this mushroom from the ground, they must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute.
A mushroom with a very strange smell.

A mushroom that invites disarray. As an action, you can crush this mushroom in your hand and blow its spores at a creature within 5 feet of you. That creature must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or become confused as if by the {@spell confusion} spell for 1 minute. A creature can repeat its saving throw at the end of its turns, ending the confusion early on a success.
A dangerous fungus said to draw the life out of people. Beware. A creature takes 1d6 necrotic damage when they pluck it from the ground.
footnotes: When you succeed on an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to locate a mushroom in an area. You must then make a Wisdom ({@skill Nature}) or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check against the locations Plant resource DC. On a success, you roll on the locations mushroom resources table.

table.name: Plants
rows: You can eat this herb as an action, curing yourself of the {@condition poisoned} condition.
A berry that explodes when subjected to an impact. Makes a firecracker-like sound.
Possess antidotal agents, but it will not work by itself.
A Mysterious berry, said to be hated by dragons.

When given to a lynian they are {@condition charmed} by you as if under the {@spell charm person} spell for 1 hour. A lynian always knows when a creature has felvine and will react violently if it is not given it willingly.
A plant that has flammable properties. Can be crushed and thrown into a campfire to light it.
You can use an action to eat this herb, regaining 1d4 hit points.
An empty berry that can grow anywhere.
A lightweight and extremely strong plant.
Berry covered in needle-like thorns. Deals 1 piercing damage when picked up.
You are cured of blight, or blight-like spells or effects when you eat this berry.
Releases a smelly paint-like juice when broken.
A plant with leaves coated in sticky sap. The sap can be used as a simple glue.
A nut that violently ejects its contents when struck.
Chewing it releases oxygen, allowing you to breathe underwater for 1 minute.
Possesses antidotal agents, but it will not work by itself.
Works as a {@item Hot Drink|AGMH} but only for 1 hour.
Works as a {@item Cool Drink|AGMH} but only for 1 hour.
A bright red strawberry from scorching climes.
A bright red strawberry from scorching climes.
When you eat this seed, your Strength score increases by +2 for 1 minute. Once the effect wears off you gain one level of {@condition exhaustion}.
A large, beautifully colored flowering plant
Upon collection the creature must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 24 hours
A plant that looks to the heavens when it blooms. Its petals are used to make dye.
footnotes: You can find plants in all regions, in all sorts of different environments. You may find them in the middle of a grassy field, up a cliff, or perhaps under a tree.

When you succeed on an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to locate a plant in an area. You must then make a Wisdom ({@skill Nature}) or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check against the locations Plant resource DC. On a success, you roll on the locations plant resources table.

variantrule.name: Monstie Sidekicks

entries: {@b Note to Players}. Это все еще находится на стадии тестирования. На бумаге это выглядит хорошо, но не каждый созданный монстр будет сбалансирован. При использовании монстров ожидайте, что вам, возможно, придется вносить коррективы по мере того, как вы будете играть с вашим DM.
{@b Note to DM}. Если вы разрешаете игрокам использовать монстров, то при определении сложности боя вы будете считать их как еще одного ПК.

A monstie is a monster that you can form bonds with. This is typically accomplished through a kinship stone or perhaps by rescuing it from near death. However, it happens you now have a {@class monstie sidekick|AGMH|friend for life}.

entries.name: Monstie Rules
entries: В Monster Hunter Monster Manual более 240 монстров, и каждый из них - чей-то любимый. Но не все монстры созданы одинаковыми, и многие из них были бы слишком сильны в качестве монстров. В связи с этим ниже приведены правила, которые помогут сбалансировать класс монстров-подручных.

entries.name: Rules
items: Старшие драконы и монстры Парагона не могут быть монстрами (у них слишком много уникальных черт и атак, чтобы пытаться их сбалансировать).
Монстр основывается на оригинальном блоке статов существа, а не на закаленной версии (подвиды, девианты и т.д. все еще можно использовать).
Все монстры при первоначальном создании используют один и тот же базовый шаблон существа.
"PB" означает бонус к мастерству при изучении этого класса бокового помощника.

entries.name: Choose your Original Monster
entries: Найдите в Руководстве по монстрам Monster Hunter монстра, соответствующего вышеуказанным правилам, который станет оригинальным монстром, на котором будет основан ваш монстрик. Ваш оригинальный монстр будет часто упоминаться по мере того, как ваш монстр будет повышать уровень и приобретать новые черты и действия.

entries.name: Create Your Monstie
entries: Используя шаблон справа и информацию ниже, соберите своего монстра первого уровня до того, как он приобретет свои начальные характеристики первого уровня.

entries.name: Ability Scores
entries: Набор очков способностей монстров: 15, 14, 13, 12, 10 и 8. Показатели способностей помещаются в блок статистики так же, как и у оригинального монстра. Если сила - самый сильный показатель способности оригинала, то сила монстра будет равна 15, так как это самый сильный показатель способности в массиве. Если сила является третьим по силе показателем способности, то вы поместите 13 в силу для монстра.
Например: {@creature rajang|MHMM} монстр будет иметь Str 15, Dex 12, Con 14, Int 10, Wis 13, Cha 8

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: Некоторые свойства вашего монстра требуют от цели броска спасброска, чтобы противостоять их эффектам. DC броска спасброска рассчитывается следующим образом:

entries.name: Monstie
attributes: appropriate Ability Score modifier for the save

entries: Когда существо успешно выполняет бросок спасения против состояния, вызванного монстром, оно получает иммунитет к этому эффекту на 24 часа.
{@b Most Common Ability Scores for Saves}
STR: быть сбитым с ног, черта заряда
CON: Дыхательные атаки, болезни, яды, рев
CHA: Страшное присутствие

entries.name: Senses
entries: Монстр получает те же чувства, что и в основном блоке ({@sense darkvision}, {@sense blindsight}, {@sense truesight}, {@sense tremorsense}), но его максимальный радиус действия составляет 30 футов. Если чувствительность исходного монстра ниже 30 футов, то чувствительность вашего монстра равна этому показателю. По мере увеличения размера монстра на 6-м уровне дальность действия его органов чувств увеличивается до 60 футов или максимальной дальности действия органов чувств исходного монстра (в зависимости от того, что меньше). На 15-м уровне этот диапазон увеличивается до 120 футов или максимального диапазона чувств исходного монстра (в зависимости от того, что меньше).

entries.name: Speed
entries: Монсти имеет те же типы движения, что и оригинальный монстр, на котором он основан, но изначально он не так быстр. Их базовая скорость ходьбы составляет 25 футов. Любой другой вид передвижения (полет, нора, лазание и т.д.) - 15 футов. Каждый раз, когда монстр повышает свой уровень, он получает дополнительные 5 футов каждого типа передвижения, вплоть до первоначального количества блоков передвижения для каждого типа.

dataCreature.name: Monstie Template

walk.condition: (+5 feet for each level until it reaches its original monsters speed); Burrow, Climb, Fly, Swim 15 ft. (if the original stat block has it, +5 feet for each level until it reaches its original monsters speed)

languages: Same as original monster; understands common, but can't speak it

action.name: One attack the original monster knows that only deals damage
entries: The {@i +to Hit} is equal to: the appropriate Ability Score Modifier plus PB. Its damage is equal to 1d#, where # is equal to the original monster's attack's damage die. The attack's reach is 5 feet if it is a melee attack. If it is a ranged attack, its range is equal to the original monster's attack range.

entries.name: Monstie Sidekick Class
entries: {@class Monstie Sidekick|AGMH}

dataCreature.name: Rajang Monstie Lvl 1
languages: understands common, but can't speak it

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Lighting Breath (2 Uses)
entries: The rajang exhales lightning in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw, taking 9 ({@damage 2d8}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

dataCreature.name: Nargacuga lvl 20
languages: understands common, but can't speak it

trait.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: While in dim light or Darkness, the Nargacuga can take the {@action Hide} action as a Bonus Action. Its stealth bonus is also improved to +17.

action.name: Extra Attack
entries: The nargacuga makes three attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Bladed Wings
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail Swipe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d12 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Tail Spikes
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Feral Pounce (6 uses).
entries: The nargacuga leaps towards a creature, jumping 10 feet as part of its movement, and attacks the creature with its bladed wing. The target must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 37 ({@damage 7d10}) piercing damage and be knocked {@condition prone} on a failed save, or half as much damage and is not knocked prone on a successful one. Additionally, if the target is prone or knocked prone, the nargacuga can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

entries.name: Step 1.
entries: When getting ready to cook a meal as an artisan, the first step is to decide on what you want to cook and ensuring you have the ingredients required for the meal. On the next page you will find a list of tables with meal names, ingredients, the DC required to cook the meal, and the boon they grant.

The ingredients themselves should be easy to obtain. They might find them near the campsite as part of preparing the meal or be able to purchase them in town for under 1 sp for a portion large enough to prepare a meal for a party of four.

entries.name: Step 2.
entries: There are multiple steps in creating a meal; {@i deciding on the recipe/what to cook, gathering ingredients, preparing the ingredients, cooking the meal, plating it properly.}

Choose three of the steps from the list above and one of the six main ability scores for each step. You cannot use the same ability score on different steps. Then describe how you use that ability score for the step you chose and make an ability score check. The DM may impose disadvantage on the check if the description is wildly improbable to work or not allow the roll.
A creature that has {@item cook's utensils|PHB|cooking utensils} and is proficient with them, can add their proficiency bonus to one of the three ability score checks.

entries.name: Step 3.
entries: Once the player has made their three checks, take the average of the checks and compare them to the DC of the meal they are attempting to make.

On a successful check the meal counts as a days ration for any who eat it and they gain the boon the meal provides. If the artisan succeeds by 4 or more, roll once on the daily skill list. If they succeed by 8 or more, roll twice on the daily skill list.

On a failed check it becomes a bland meal and counts as 1 days ration. If the artisan fails the check by 5 or more, it does not count as a ration and any creature who eats the meal must succeed on a Constitution saving throw equal to the meals DC or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour.

entries.name: Let's look at an Example
entries: Zuri the half-orc fighter has taken on the role of artisan on a hunt in the Verdant Hills. As the group wakes up in the early morning she begins preparing a meal for all of them. The following is what the player describes:

{@i Zuri looks around and spies some fruit high up in a tree that she thinks she could turn into a sauce. she climbs up the tree} {@b (Strength)} {@i plucking the fruit as she goes. Back at the campfire with fruit in hand, she thinks about the type of meal she wants to make} {@b (Intelligence)}. {@i Deciding on the meal, Zuri spends the rest of her time over a sweltering hot fire} {@b (Constitution)} {@i cooking the meal to perfection.}

This example doesn't go into excruciating detail, and in some cases allows the player to make some things up. I didn't have Zuri make a perception check to find the fruit, instead the Strength check either allowed her to gather as many as she wanted for the meal or perhaps on a failed save, they aren't ripe, already rotting when she gets to them, or they are on small thin branches preventing her from getting more than few of them. Most importantly, passing or failing on a single check does not matter. What matters is if Zuri succeeded well enough overall to pass the meals check DC.

On a successful check, Zuri was able to create the meal even though she may have experienced a few hiccups along the way and could be narratively described based on the checks that scored below the meals DC. Say she failed on her strength but succeeded on both the intelligence and constitution checks. Narratively it could be described as Zuri struggling to find enough fruit for the meal, but made up for its missing component by adjusting the recipe and taking the meal off the fire a little earlier than normal to deal with this challenge.

On a failed check, Zuri was unable to create the meal as she had planned, this could be due to a lack of fruit she was able to obtain, her recipe was incorrect, or perhaps she removed it from the fire too soon. Depending on how badly she failed the check, it could still be edible, but bland, or it could cause someone some stomach issues for a bit.

entries.name: Ingredient Cost
entries: There is always a cost when cooking a meal. Wether you use your supplies to go out and collect local foliage and fauna or purchase it in the market. The cost of preparing a meal depends on its rank. A Rank 1 meal costs 1 sp; Rank 2 meals, 1 gp; Rank 3 meals, 5 gp; and Rank 4 meals, 10 gp.

entries.name: Cooking higher ranked meals
entries: More recipes will become available to you as you increase your hunter rank.
You are able to cook rank 2 meals at 5th level, rank 3 meals at 10th level, rank 4 meals at 15th level.

entries.caption: Rank 1
rows: You count as if you were one size larger for the purpose of determining your carrying capacity.
You gain the same benefits as if you drank a {@item cool drink|AGMH}.
You can doff or don your armor as an action.
You have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks to catch {@table insects|AGMH}.
You gain the same benefits as if you drank a {@item hot drink|AGMH}.
Reduces the casting time of rituals by half.
Once per meal, you can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to one saving throw of your choice. You can roll the die before or after making the saving throw.
Once per meal, when you fail a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration, you can reroll the d20, taking the new result.
Your passive Perception is increased by 1.
As a bonus action, you can make a DC 15 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. If you succeed, difficult terrain doesn't cost you extra movement until the end of the current turn.
You have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Athletics}) checks to catch {@table fish|AGMH}.
While holding your weapon in darkness it sheds moonlight, creating bright light in a 15-foot radius and dim light for an additional 15 feet.
Once per meal, you can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to one ability check of your choice. You can roll the die before or after making the ability check.
You have blindsight out to a range of 5 feet.
Your swim speed is increased by 5 feet.
Your walking speed is increased by 5 feet.
If you do not expend any hit die on a short rest, you regain one instead.
One creature that eats this meal (artisan's choice) adds an extra 1d4 to Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks to find resources.
footnotes: {@i *DC is increased by 1 for each serving over 4}

entries.caption: Rank 2
rows: Once per meal, you may ignore the verbal and/or somatic components of a spell you are casting.
When you would take fall damage, you reduce the damage you take by your proficiency bonus.
Your life signs become imperceptible by nonmagical means.
Your passive Perception is increased by 2.
You gain the same benefits as if you had the {@feat Athlete} feat, but it does not increase your ability score.
You gain the same benefits as if you had the {@feat Actor} feat, but it does not increase your ability score.
You can sense the presence and location of poisons, poisonous creatures, and diseases within 30 feet of you.
Once per meal, when you fail a carve check, you can reroll the d20 and take the new roll.
You have advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) checks to gather plants and mushrooms.

You can use a bonus action to conjure two earplugs in the shape of your choice. While using these earplugs, you are considered {@condition deafened}. You can dispel the ear plugs as a bonus action ending the deafened effect.
When you take the {@action dodge} action on your turn, until the start of your next turn, any damage you take is reduced by an amount equal to your Dexterity modifier.
Choose a rank 1 meal that has a once per meal effect. You gain that meals effect and it can now be used twice per meal.
Ranged weapons can be fired underwater at no penalty.

A creature that eats this meal gains the same benefits as if the {@spell aid} spell was cast on them. This meal can be cooked at a higher rank (+2 to the DC for each rank higher), increasing level of the spell cast by 1 for each rank.
Once per meal when you roll on a creatures loot table, you can choose to reroll it and take the new roll.
You have advantage on Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks to mine ore.
The artisan receives an omen as if by the {@spell augury} spell. The omen they receive is about all who eat the meal, not just the themselves.
footnotes: {@i *DC is increased by 2 for each serving over 4}

entries.caption: Rank 3
rows: You gain the same benefits as if you had the {@feat Tavern Brawler} feat, but it does not increase your ability score.
Your passive Perception is increased by 3.
If your Dexterity score is over 15, you have advantage on Initiative rolls.
You can understand any spoken language you hear, but you cannot speak it.
You have advantage on {@skill intimidation} and {@skill persuasion} checks when interacting with lynians for 8 hours.
You have advantage on {@skill intimidation} and {@skill persuasion} checks when interacting with wyverians for 8 hours.
You ignore difficult terrain if it was not created by a magical effect.
You ignore difficult terrain if it was not created by a magical effect.
You have advantage on ability checks made to resist being {@condition grappled}.
You automatically succeed on all Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks when mining.
Once per meal, when you must make a saving throw, you can choose to do so with advantage.
You have advantage on all carve checks.
You can breath underwater and you have a swim speed of 60 feet.
A single creature that eats this meal gains the same benefits as if they had the {@feat Inspiring Leader} feat.
You have darkvision out to 60 feet for 24 hours.
You gain the same benefits as if you had the {@feat Dungeon Delver} feat.

A single creature (artisan's choice) that eats this meal gains the ability to cast the {@spell earthbind|XGE} spell once within the next 8 hours and they do not have to concentrate on the spell. The spell save DC is 15 or their spellcasting save DC, whichever is higher.
You gain the same benefits as if you had the {@feat Keen Mind} feat, but you can only recall anything you have seen or heard since your last meal.
footnotes: {@i *DC is increased by 2 for each serving over 4}

entries.caption: Rank 4
rows: Once per meal, when you miss with a melee weapon attack, you can choose to hit instead.
Once per meal, you can use your action to teleport yourself back to the location where you ate this meal, so long as it is within 1 mile of where you are at.
Once per meal, as an action, you can cast the {@spell misty step} spell, without using a spell slot or any components.
You have advantage on Constitution saving throws.
You can speak telepathically with any creature who ate this meal so long as they are within 60 feet of you.
When you would take fall damage, you reduce the damage you take by half your character level.
Your passive Perception is increased by 4.
Once per meal, when you take damage from any source, you can reduce that damage to 0.
You have advantage on saving throws against the {@condition poisoned} condition.
Dim light doesn't impose disadvantage on your Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks relying on sight.
Once per meal, you can add a d10 roll to any ability check, attack roll, or saving throw you make.
Once per meal, you can use a bonus action to regenerate a number of hit points equal to 10 + your character level.
You gain a flying speed of 30 feet.
You are able to find the most direct physical route to a specific fixed location that you are familiar with on the same plane of existence.
footnotes: {@i *DC is increased by 2 for each serving over 4}

entries.name: Daily skills
entries: If the skill doesn't specify a duration, the effect lasts for 24 hours, until you finish a long rest, or until you eat another meal. When you roll on the daily skill list below, roll a 1d20 plus 1d6 - 1.

items.name: Felyne Weathercat
entries: Foul weather occurs more often during a quest (Heavy rain, blizzards, sandstorms, etc).

items.name: Felyne Swimmer
entries: Your swim speed is increased by 15 feet.

items.name: Felyne Fur Coating
entries: You take half as much damage from environmental hazards and blight effects.

items.name: Felyne Gatherer (Lo)
entries: Increase the number of resources you can gain on a hunt by 2.

items.name: Felyne Backer
entries: Prevents being knocked {@condition prone} when transporting items.

items.name: Felyne Provoker
entries: When a creature within 5 feet of you is hit by a melee weapon attack, you can use your reaction to redirect the damage to you.

items.name: Felyne Researcher
entries: You are able to immediately identify any materials effects as soon as you touch them. Additionally, you can add both your Wisdom and Intelligence ability modifiers to any one {@skill History} or {@skill Nature} check.

items.name: Felyne Escape Artist
entries: You have advantage on Strength ({@skill Athletics}) and Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) checks when attempting to escape from a creature or object that has you {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained}.

items.name: Felyne Insurance
entries: The first time you or an ally drops to 0 hit points on the hunt, they instead drop to 1 hit point.

items.name: Felyne Crafter
entries: You have a +2 bonus to crafting checks.

items.name: Felyne Medic
entries: Health recovery items add 1 extra die.

items.name: Felyne Fisher
entries: You have advantage on skill checks when fishing.

items.name: Felyne Sprinter
entries: When you take the dash action, you can move an extra 10 feet.

items.name: Felyne Gatherer (Hi)
entries: Double the amount of resources you can gain on a hunt.

items.name: Felyne Cliffhanger
entries: You have a climbing speed of 20 feet.

items.name: Felyne Lander
entries: You always land on your feet when falling from a height greater than 10 feet. This does not prevent the damage you would still take.

items.name: Felyne Parting Gift
entries: The first time an ally drops to 0 hit points during a hunt, they can choose up to 6 creatures in a 30-foot radius of them. Those creatures are healed for 2d6 hit points.

items.name: Felyne Dungmaster
entries: A creature hit by a {@item dung bomb|AGMH} must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or immediately use its reaction, if available, to move as far as its speed allows away from you. The creature doesn't move into obviously dangerous ground, such as fire or a pit.

items.name: Felyne Inspiration
entries: You gain inspiration.

items.name: Felyne Foodie
entries: The food bonus lasts for 48 hours, you cannot become inebriated during this time, and you can cast the {@spell thaumaturgy} spell at will.

items.name: Felyne Courage
entries: If you are {@condition frightened}, you can choose to repeat your saving throw at the start of your turn instead of the end.

items.name: Felyne Rider
entries: You have advantage on checks to stay mounted on monsters.

items.name: Felyne Cleats
entries: Your movement is unaffected by the first 15 feet of difficult terrain (magical or otherwise) you move through on your turn.

items.name: Felyne Bomb Expert
entries: {@filter Barrel bombs and thrown bombs|items|source=AGMH|type=Explosive} gain a +1 bonus to their range attack roll or save DC.

items.name: Felyne Oracle
entries: Hunt begins with one sign found.

variantrule.name: Downtime Activity: Solo Hunt
entries: Sometimes it is easier to hunt alone. This activity gives a character the chance to obtain some extra materials from creatures. The table below shows the maximum CR a character can hunt depending on their level and difficulty they choose. Once they choose their difficulty, they can then pick the creature they are hunting.

entries.name: Resources
entries: This activity requires one workweek of effort plus 100 gp to pay for research and supplies to hunt a medium. A character can hunt a hard encounter for 150 gp to cover expenses, or 200 gp for a deadly encounter.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: The character must make a series of checks, with the DC for all the checks determined by the difficulty of the encounter. The chosen DC for medium is equal to the creature's carve DC. A hard encounter is the creature's carve DC +3 and deadly is the creature's carve DC +6. Successful completion of the hunt yields a number of materials, as shown on the Loot Value table.

To attempt a Hunt, the character makes three checks: Wisdom ({@skill Perception}), Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}), and the player's choice of Wisdom ({@skill Survival}), Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}), or Strength ({@skill Athletics}).
If none of the checks are successful, the character is severely injured and hospitalized. The injured character must spend one week in the hospital for every 50g of the initial cost of the hunt.
If only one check is successful, the hunt fails but the character escapes.
If two checks are successful, the hunt is a partial success, netting the character one material from the creature. Roll on the loot table to determine which.
If all three checks are successful, the character earns three materials from the creature. Roll on the loot table for each material to determine which materials are obtained.

variantrule.name: Downtime Activity: Trenya
entries: Trenya travels to various regions in his boat. A character can travel with Trenya on adventures. Trenya can help gather items for hunters, some of which can only be obtained through him. Trenya is a great way to gather materials for upgrading weapons and armor.

entries.name: Resources
entries: This activity requires one workweek of effort and the character chooses the location for the adventure. The character has a choice between these locations: snowy mountains, jungle, desert, or swamp. Once the location is set, the character pays Trenya 200gp, 500gp, or 1500gp.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: Depending on the location and how much the character spent they will need to make a number of checks; a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check, a Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check, an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, and a Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Persuasion}, or {@skill Deception}) check. The character can only use each skill once and once they fail a check the adventure is over and they return home.
If only one check is successful, the character rolls on the general section of the table.
If two checks are successful, the character rolls on the first and second level of the table.
If three checks are successful, the character rolls on the first, second, and third level of the table.
If four checks are successful, the character rolls on the fourth and below levels of the table. If there is no fourth level or higher, the character may roll once again on a previous level.
If all five checks are successful, the character rolls on each level of the table. If there is no fifth level, the character may roll once again on a previous level.

{@i Some of the items listed on Trenya loot tables do not yet have a purpose. Either the creature's loot table has not been created as of yet, their purpose has not yet been determined, or they are junk that only has a gold value.}

variantrule.name: Downtime Activity: Sell Materials
entries: Selling materials can be a difficult task at times. Demand is not always there and even if you have a legitimate buyer for one you may still not get the price you are expecting.

entries.name: Resources
entries: A character can find a buyer for a specific material by spending one workweek and 25gp, which is used to spread word of the desired sale. A character can pick up to 10 materials at a time to sell.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: A character who wants to sell materials must make a Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check to determine what kind of offer comes in. The character can always opt not to sell, instead forfeiting the workweek of effort and trying again later. Use the Material Base Price and Material Item Offer tables below to determine the sale price.

entries.caption: Material Base Price
footnotes: {@i *All materials are the same price from a creature based on its CR level.}

variantrule.name: Downtime Activity: Palico Farm
entries: A character who has the time, the money, and the needed tools can use downtime collecting resources at the palico farm.

entries.name: Resources
entries: This activity requires access to a farm run by felyne and melynx (typically found in any village or town), one workweek of effort plus a cost of 25 gp for access to the farm and tools required for the work.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: Choose a location stat block appropriate for your level or lower, and the area you are in. The character then chooses three resources to collect between: {@table fish|AGMH}, {@table insects|AGMH}, {@table mushrooms|AGMH}, or {@table plants|AGMH}. The character can pick the same resource multiple times, but they cannot pick a resource that is not on the location stat block they chose. The character then makes three skill checks, one for each resource they chose. The DC is equal to the resource DC in the location stat block.

The type of check they make depends on the resource they are attempting to obtain. For fish, they make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check. For insects, they make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) or Wisdom ({@skill Nature}) check. For mushrooms, they make a Wisdom ({@skill Nature}) or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check. For plants, they make a Wisdom ({@skill Nature}) or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check.
For each successful check, the character rolls on the location stat blocks resource table, gaining the resource listed.

entries.name: Complications
entries: Complications while farming usually relate to the maintenance of the tools to gather the resources. Whenever a character starts a workweek on the palico farm, there is a 10 percent chance of one of the tools being unavailable due to maintenance. Roll on the complication table to determine why certain resources can't be collected this workweek.

rows: The Fishing Pole is broken, a new one won't arrive for a workweek. The character can't collect fish.
The bugnet is filled with more holes than actual netting. The character can't collect insects.
The fields were just seeded, there are currently no plants to collect.
A mosswine got into the mushroom cave and ate every last mushroom. The character can't collect mushrooms to do this.

variantrule.name: Combo List
entries: Many of the items found in the Monster Hunter Universe can be crafted using resources and materials found during your travels. Below you will find lists of items you can make with each tool, the required ingredients, how difficult it will be to make, and how much is created on a successful crafting check.

An item may appear more than once on any given list, requiring a different combination of items to craft. An item may also appear under two or more tools, in which case you may choose which tool you use to craft it.

entries.name: Using the Combo List
entries: Any PC can create any of the items in the combo list so long as they have the tool required. {@b They do not need to be proficient with the tool.}

To craft an item from the combo list, the PC chooses the item they wish to create. So long as they have the tool, the required items, and enough time (determined by the DM) to create the item; then the PC makes a crafting check.

entries.name: Crafting Check:
entries: 1d20 + their ability score modifier + their proficiency bonus (if they are proficient with the tool)

On a successful crafting check, the required items are consumed and the item is crafted. If the crafting check fails by 5 or less, only 1 of the required items (PC's choice) is consumed. If they fail the check by 6 or more, both required items are consumed.

entries.name: Not sure what Ability Score to Use?
entries: Tools are not tied to a single ability, since proficiency with a tool represents broader knowledge of its use. A player can make a case to their DM on which ability score to use, but sometimes a DM may not agree or might be unsure on which ability score to have the PC use. If you are unsure of what skill to use, both Wisdom or Intelligence are great options to use.

Wisdom can be viewed as experience or natural talent with the tool. Think of it like a baker who doesn't measure their ingredients for a cake and adapts the recipe to what they think it should be, and the cake still ends up tasting amazing. While Intelligence can be used for the PC's retained knowledge or ability to follow instructions. This is the baker who follows the exact directions and the cake comes out exactly as expected.

entries.name: Combo Books
entries: There are 5 volumes in the Combo Book Collection. These books were written by an ancient civilization, but lost to the ages long ago. A Hunter may stumble upon one or more of these intact books while out on an adventure or hunt. While the book remains in their possession, they gain a +1 bonus to crafting checks. This bonus is increased by 1 for each different volume they possess.
